comments.author: Julius Bernotas

comments.text:
This is a fascinating topic! How memory and smell go hand in hand so much 
that I intentionally go beyond in seeking out long lost scents made by turn 
of the century perfume masters. When recalling my Grandfather who wore a 
smell that for years I had no idea what it was, no one could tell me either 
(make sure you tell your kids what it is you love, so they know) Fast 
forward 20 years; I came across Jo Malone's perfumes (lovely for strict top 
notes and how long it lasts.) The lime basil brought me back to the memory 
of that New Yorker who stood as tall as the trees, bowled like a demon and 
always had a huge cigar with his smile. So this "scentual science" 
experiement hit home with me.
I am involved with a long time friend who does this very same thing but for 
life and health. Like many of us who are invested/interested in this 
particular topic began searching for but not finding anything at all, and 
what was found was so dissapointing or had chemicals known for physical 
irritations/carcinogens. Bummed and pissed off by the balls that 
some retailers had the nerve of asking $22.00 for a tiny bit of product 
that lacked something that was given the title of smells like such and 
such(..fill in the blank for the scents) As a finnicky person this 
musician/professional friend & photographer of many of our favored 
metal/stoner bands.. turned to doing it herself.
What resulted in all this time invested resulted in what has been around 
before and found once again. Made in limited numbers because there is care 
in whats being shared and We're on that little site called Etsy under Barn 
Cat Farm Soap
We went out of our way to produce a group of small batch seasonal organic 
soaps that is intentionally bitch packed with scent! Big for man's hands, 
long cured and cut by hand. It's addictive once you start smelling 
something and want to sniff it again and again. Destin, you are so 
romantic..You are a Great husband!
comments.author: L8dyAriel

Really enjoy the series. There are so many variables to account for. That 
"smell" is only but one memory a new born will register and build upon.

and change as we grow. As always great scientific execution.

top_comment.text:
Your own pheromones will interact with the cologne, and also the woman's 
tainted sense of smell (for example, we are born naturally repelled by 
the pheromones of our own family members).  Point being, smells vary for 
everybody and each person will interpret the smell of a same cologne 
differently. ﻿

comments.text:
+SmarterEveryDay
"power" over your wife's nose? I'm sorry, but I find that somewhat creepy. 
I won't tell you what to do, but in my opinion, if she loves you for who 
you are the cologne used as a memory trigger shouldn't matter as much on 
another person or place. I believe that there is an important distinction 
between finding someone attractive and being attracted to them. For 
example: I find my friend Sophia attractive. Would I ever date her? No, 
because I am not romantically interested in her. I find her scent to be 
pleasing and her body to have a nice figure. But I don't feel romantic with 
her, she is just a beautiful friend. My boyfriend is someone I am attracted 
to because I have a romantic relationship with him. And just to specify, by 
romance, I do not mean sex, I mean a special feeling that is shared as a 
bond. I'd also like to specify that in my example, gender bias concerning 
my sexuality would not apply since I am bisexual.
comments.author: knittinninja

smell quite the same as it does on you.

comments.author: Sudonym Rodriguez

captions.text: Hey it's me Destin,
welcome back to Smarter Every Day.
This is my buddy Ben,
and he got a new toy,
so we're gonna try to shoot with this.
Just because we want to try it.
Show em what it does.
Do I have to stand right here?
(Ben) Yes.
OK, here we go.
Alright so today on Smarter Every Day
I am gonna tell you how I determined my cologne,
my man smell.
And the way I did it was using the scientific method
but the reason I did it is pretty interesting.
You know that smell is linked to memory.
So I used to squirrel hunt here and it smells
like childhood to me, it's pretty interesting.
You probably have things like that in your life.
Like honeysuckles might remind you of your grandmother
or something like that.
So today on Smarter Every Day I'm gonna show you
how I selected that cologne, because after all
I wanted to be really desirable for my wife right?
Here we go. Hypothesis.
If people like different smells, I should be able to
test scientifically to determine the optimum smell
for my wife, which I can then wear consistently
and hopefully trigger memories about me when I'm not around.
But first we've got to figure out how to set up this experiment.
I searched the internet trying to find out which colognes
women seem to prefer most.
I Googled the popular brands but realized quickly
that this was influenced by marketing, so instead
I went to Two X to try to get opinions of women
talking to other women about their men.
This gave me some good preliminary data.
But then I went to the Smarter Every Day Facebook page
and asked everyone on there which colognes they preferred.
This is where I started to see some clear front runners,
which made me wonder if I really wanted to smell like
every other man in the world.
There were over 300 unique responses submitted
by 800 different comments.
Clearly I can't afford a bottle of each of these colognes.
If you've ever looked at how much these things cost
you'd know that this experiment is about to get expensive.
I was surprised to find that there are web sites that buy
huge bottle of name brand cologne and divide them up
into smaller samples, but 200 colognes is still way too many to try.
So I asked my friend Will Leahy to compile all this survey data
up together into one chart.
Clearly women respond well to the smells on the left side of this chart,
so keeping that in mind, obviously I want to get a larger sample
of the fragrances on that side.
However I realized that this could also mean that these brands are
simply marketed more effectively.
So to keep things fair I chose several colognes that weren't as popular.
Once I cut away the less interesting candidates
I narrowed it down to a manageable size that I felt like I could test
over a six month period, and here they are.
There's a broad spectrum represented here.
There's super expensive stuff, cheap stuff,
popular stuff, and stuff that's less known.
At this point, I would have been willing to bet
